articles.headline: Urged to Launch an Attack, Trump Listened to the Skeptics Who Said It Would Be a Costly Mistake
articles.snippet: Meetings and memos aside, the president trusted his instincts more than institutions and was willing to defy a roomful of advisers.
articles.abstract: Meetings and memos aside, the president trusted his instincts more than institutions and was willing to defy a roomful of advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He heard from his generals and his diplomats. Lawmakers weighed in and so did his advisers. But among the voices that rang powerfully for President Trump was that of one of his favorite Fox News hosts: Tucker Carlson.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: L.A. to Vegas and Back by Electric Car: 8 Hours Driving; 5 More Plugged In
articles.snippet: You’ll need to charge your vehicle more often than filling a gas tank, it takes longer, and the chargers can be scarce. Here’s how one road trip went.
articles.abstract: You’ll need to charge your vehicle more often than filling a gas tank, it takes longer, and the chargers can be scarce. Here’s how one road trip went.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You’ve heard it many times, from automakers, the energy industry and government officials: Electric vehicles are the cars of the future, essential to the fight against climate change.

articles.headline: Who Gets to Own the West?
articles.snippet: A new group of billionaires is shaking up the landscape.
articles.abstract: A new group of billionaires is shaking up the landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: IDAHO CITY, Idaho — The Wilks brothers grew up in a goat shed, never finished high school and built a billion-dollar fracking business from scratch.

articles.headline: ‘The Black Vote Is Not Monolithic’: 2020 Democrats Find Split Preferences in South Carolina
articles.snippet: Though many African-Americans in South Carolina have favored Joseph R. Biden Jr. they are taking a hard look at several other candidates and considering all issues, not just race.
articles.abstract: Though many African-Americans in South Carolina have favored Joseph R. Biden Jr. they are taking a hard look at several other candidates and considering all issues, not just race.
articles.lead_paragraph: McCLELLANVILLE, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. enjoys a sizable advantage with black voters in South Carolina right now, and not just at lunch tables where they discuss candidates over freshly caught shrimp and fried fish. Recent polls have shown him with support from about 50 percent of African-American voters in the state.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Facing Intensifying Confrontation With Iran, Trump Has Few Appealing Options
articles.snippet: The administration is relying first on economic sanctions to change Tehran’s behavior. But it continues to weigh military or cyberattacks.
articles.abstract: The administration is relying first on economic sanctions to change Tehran’s behavior. But it continues to weigh military or cyberattacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s last-minute decision to pull back from a retaliatory strike on Iran underscored the absence of appealing options available to him as Tehran races toward its next big challenge to the United States: building up and further enriching its stockpile of nuclear fuel.

articles.headline: Iranian Force Exults in Downing of U.S. Drone With a Feast and a Prayer
articles.snippet: Some leaders of the Revolutionary Guards force saw the shooting down of the drone as a vindication. They resented that Americans had belittled their prowess.
articles.abstract: Some leaders of the Revolutionary Guards force saw the shooting down of the drone as a vindication. They resented that Americans had belittled their prowess.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seated on the floor of a villa in northeast Tehran around a tablecloth spread with platters of saffron chicken and rice with barberries, about 30 officials of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and guests gathered Thursday night for a prayerful celebration.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: ‘The Rooster Must Be Defended’: France’s Culture Clash Reaches a Coop
articles.snippet: A dispute between residents of a small island off France’s western coast and summer vacationers taps into France’s still unbroken connection to its agricultural past.
articles.abstract: A dispute between residents of a small island off France’s western coast and summer vacationers taps into France’s still unbroken connection to its agricultural past.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAINT-PIERRE-D’OLÉRON, France — The rooster was annoyed and off his game. He shuffled, clucked and puffed out his russet plumage. But he didn’t crow. Not in front of all these strangers.

articles.headline: Turkey’s President Suffers Stinging Defeat in Istanbul Election Redo
articles.snippet: Voters were outraged that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered a redo of the same election two months ago after his party lost control of Turkey’s largest city.
articles.abstract: Voters were outraged that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered a redo of the same election two months ago after his party lost control of Turkey’s largest city.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey suffered the biggest defeat of his political career on Sunday as his candidate for Istanbul mayor conceded defeat in a repeat election.

articles.headline: Trump’s Iran Reversal Raises Allies’ Doubts Over His Tactics, and U.S. Power
articles.snippet: The public response of Western politicians has been largely cautious, sometimes confused. But some analysts also praised Mr. Trump’s restraint.
articles.abstract: The public response of Western politicians has been largely cautious, sometimes confused. But some analysts also praised Mr. Trump’s restraint.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Some framed it as another empty threat from a leader whose bark is consistently worse than his bite. Some saw a method to the perceived madness — a potentially shrewd act of brinkmanship.

articles.headline: 5 Lessons From Microsoft’s Antitrust Woes, by People Who Lived It
articles.snippet: The Microsoft case from the 1990s provides a road map for today’s tech giants and regulators.
articles.abstract: The Microsoft case from the 1990s provides a road map for today’s tech giants and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s antitrust enforcers and Congress are stepping up their scrutiny of the tech giants. Disruptive investigations, federal lawsuits and new rules could loom for Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple.

articles.headline: What Happens After Amazon’s Domination Is Complete? Its Bookstore Offers Clues
articles.snippet: Popular novels, technical tomes and self-published books are pirated and sold on Amazon. That may actually be helping the company extend its grip on the book business.
articles.abstract: Popular novels, technical tomes and self-published books are pirated and sold on Amazon. That may actually be helping the company extend its grip on the book business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPERRYVILLE, Va. — “The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy” is a medical handbook that recommends the right amount of the right drug for treating ailments from bacterial pneumonia to infected wounds. Lives depend on it.

articles.headline: A Machine May Not Take Your Job, but One Could Become Your Boss
articles.snippet: The goal of automation has always been efficiency. What if artificial intelligence sees humanity itself as the thing to be optimized?
articles.abstract: The goal of automation has always been efficiency. What if artificial intelligence sees humanity itself as the thing to be optimized?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Conor Sprouls, a customer service representative in the call center of the insurance giant MetLife talks to a customer over the phone, he keeps one eye on the bottom-right corner of his screen. There, in a little blue box, A.I. tells him how he’s doing.

articles.headline: At Town Hall, Pete Buttigieg Confronts Tensions Around South Bend Police Shooting
articles.snippet: The fatal shooting last week of a black man by a South Bend police officer has tested Mr. Buttigieg’s leadership at a critical time for his campaign.
articles.abstract: The fatal shooting last week of a black man by a South Bend police officer has tested Mr. Buttigieg’s leadership at a critical time for his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — It has been one of the biggest challenges for Pete Buttigieg since he began his improbable presidential campaign in January: Could the Harvard-educated mayor of South Bend, who often comes across like the brainy technocrat he once was as a McKinsey & Company consultant, build a following among black voters, one of the Democratic Party’s most vital constituencies?
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: In Streaming Age, Classical Music Gets Lost in the Metadata
articles.snippet: Has music streaming ignored aficionados of Mozart and Beethoven? Two new services, Idagio and Primephonic, address the needs of the genre’s discerning listeners.
articles.abstract: Has music streaming ignored aficionados of Mozart and Beethoven? Two new services, Idagio and Primephonic, address the needs of the genre’s discerning listeners.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Roopa Kalyanaraman Marcello, a classical music aficionado in Brooklyn, asked her Amazon Echo for some music recently, she had a specific request: the third movement of Beethoven’s “Emperor” Concerto.

articles.headline: Crisis Hits Dominican Republic Over Deaths of U.S. Tourists
articles.snippet: Officials in the Dominican Republic are struggling to explain the deaths of at least 10 American tourists in recent months, and say they are a target of an exaggerated campaign of “fake news.”
articles.abstract: Officials in the Dominican Republic are struggling to explain the deaths of at least 10 American tourists in recent months, and say they are a target of an exaggerated campaign of “fake news.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — The tourism minister grimaced as he read aloud the causes of death in autopsy reports of the growing number of Americans who have died recently while vacationing in the Dominican Republic: Heart attack. Septic shock. Pneumonia.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: A Message From the Billionaire’s Club: Tax Us
articles.snippet: A group of wealthy Americans, some with inheritances and some with self-made fortunes, are calling for a tax on the net worth of people like them.
articles.abstract: A group of wealthy Americans, some with inheritances and some with self-made fortunes, are calling for a tax on the net worth of people like them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Enthusiasm for a wealth tax on the country’s thin sliver of multimillionaires and billionaires may be unsurprising — after all, most Americans wouldn’t have to pay it. But now the idea is attracting support from a handful of those who would.

articles.headline: Glare Falls on Nissan’s C.E.O. as Ghosn Fallout Spreads
articles.snippet: Seven months after the fall of Carlos Ghosn, Nissan’s chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa, is facing questions about his own competence and probity.
articles.abstract: Seven months after the fall of Carlos Ghosn, Nissan’s chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa, is facing questions about his own competence and probity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nissan’s chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa, is in the toughest fight of his corporate life. And it’s all Carlos Ghosn’s fault.

articles.headline: Chinese Drones Made in America: One Company’s Plan to Win Over Trump
articles.snippet: The world’s largest drone maker is the latest Chinese technology company scrambling to retain their ability to sell to the United States.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest drone maker is the latest Chinese technology company scrambling to retain their ability to sell to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DJI, the large Chinese drone maker, is facing mounting security concerns within the Trump administration that its flying machines could send sensitive surveillance data back to China. Now, the company is trying to get on American officials’ good side by building some products in the United States.

articles.headline: Mexico’s Crackdown at Its Southern Border, Prompted by Trump, Scares Migrants From Crossing
articles.snippet: Increased enforcement along the border with Guatemala, which began in recent days, has made crossing into Mexico harder. This has dissuaded migrants from traveling north.
articles.abstract: Increased enforcement along the border with Guatemala, which began in recent days, has made crossing into Mexico harder. This has dissuaded migrants from traveling north.
articles.lead_paragraph: NENTÓN, Guatemala — The Aguilar family had been preparing since February to migrate north. They borrowed $2,600, made a down payment to a smuggler and set off from their home in northern Guatemala last week.
articles.byline: By Maya Averbuch and Kirk Semple
